title: 106_hr2651
content: The Physician Self-Referral Amendments of 1999 include eliminating restrictions on physician referrals, exceptions to ownership referral prohibitions, changing the definition of group practice, delaying implementation of ownership referral changes, excluding certain medical devices, and permitting supervision of clinical laboratory services by independent contractors. Eliminating restrictions on physician referrals based on compensation arrangements. Amendment to the Social Security Act allows ownership or investment interest in entities through equity, with exceptions for publicly traded securities and mutual funds. Conforming amendments are made to eliminate restrictions on physician referrals based on compensation arrangements. Amendment to the Social Security Act allows ownership or investment interest in entities through equity, with exceptions for publicly traded securities and mutual funds. Conforming amendments eliminate restrictions on physician referrals based on compensation arrangements. Subsection (d) is revised by redesignating paragraphs and transferring them after paragraph (3) of subsection (b), while subsection (e) is removed. Subsection (f) is amended by striking certain language related to ownership, investment, and compensation. In subsection (f), ownership and investment details are revised, removing references to compensation relationships. In subsection (h), paragraphs (1), (2), and (3) are eliminated, and rules for faculty are clarified. SEC. 3. EXCEPTIONS TO OWNERSHIP REFERRAL PROHIBITIONS. Revisions to Exception for In-Office Ancillary Services include repealing the site-of-service requirement and defining general supervision for individuals under a physician in the group practice. The text chunk discusses the requirement for individuals under a physician in a group practice to be under general supervision, clarifies the treatment of physician owners of group practices, and includes a conforming amendment. The text chunk amends the heading of Section 1877(b)(2) of the Act regarding ancillary services provided by physician owners of group practices and clarifies the exception for services furnished in a rural area. The text chunk modifies the definition of group practice in the Social Security Act, specifying that a physician is considered a 'member' of a group if they are an owner or employee of the group. Additionally, it delays the implementation of ownership referral changes until final regulations are issued. SEC. 5 delays ownership referral changes until final regulations are issued. SEC. 6 excludes intraocular lenses, eyeglasses, and contact lenses. SEC. 7 allows pathologists who are independent contractors to supervise clinical laboratory services. SEC. 7 permits pathologists who are independent contractors to supervise clinical laboratory services within a group practice. SEC. 8 states that the amendments in this Act apply to referrals made after the enactment date, regardless of regulations.
